A classic sci-fi shooter. The gameplay is good, the graphics were good for their time and the story was interesting. I wasn't into the game as a kid since we all played Counter Strike and other games. I didn't even know that when you instal CS you get this as well. Always thought it was just a mod for multiplayer. When I found out that I was wrong I gave this game a shot. It was good but I wasn't amazed by it. The story was also something I've already seen since I was big fan of science-fiction since I was a little kid.

Este juego en si no se compara con otros, una obra maestra con una historia compleja e intrigante que dan ganas de seguir en el juego para saber como continua, lo que si, los sustos nunca faltan pero hacen su esencia que Half Life sea unico y muy adelantado a su epoca a su fecha de salida y debut, me hubiese gustado el sistema de sonidos de pasos enemigos para asi ser mas habilidoso y saber cuando y donde estara, sin duda alguna este juego es muy bueno y entretenido, mis 8/10

[h1] Half-Life: An FPS Classic [/h1]
[b]Introduction to Half-Life[/b]
Half-Life is about a scientist named Gordon Freeman who has to survive aliens and military soldiers after an experiment goes horribly wrong, transporting various types of aliens to several facilities that Gordon will visit during the course of the game. This is the general, simplified plot of Half-Life.
The story for this game isn't told in traditional cutscenes, instead being presented through NPC dialogue and part of the gameplay as well. The story in general is interesting and stays solid throughout the campaign.

[b]Half-Life's Gameplay and Features[/b]
The gameplay is definitely the best part of this game though. The gun animations are solid, each weapon feels right, and they are mostly balanced. Though I have to say, the magnum and crossbow are some of the more OP weapons. Each type of enemy AI is easy to learn and can be taken out with almost any weapon Gordon has on him, but certain enemies later in the game can get a little annoying to deal with at times. 
Gordon can also encounter scientists and security guards, both of which can follow him around as allies, but they aren't of much help, so most of the journey is done solo. Scientists aren't really good for much else than opening up a locked door or two. Security guards have the same ability as scientists and they can attack enemies for you, but they only have a pistol. Gordon's allies aren't very durable either, so don't expect them to last long in a fight.

Aside from the gunfights, this game also has platforms to cross and puzzles to solve (Platforming in an FPS of all games, sounds crazy doesn't it?) You don't see that in FPS games nowadays. Most of the platforming sections this game throws at you aren't all that bad and can be jumped easily, though there are some parts that will require some more precise movements. Puzzles are also fairly easy to solve, but there was a couple that stumped me for a good while. While they were unexpected, the platforming and puzzle sections in this game give Half-Life a unique sense of identity, making it more unique than other games in the genre.

[b]The length of the original Half-Life[/b]
One playthrough of Half-Life's singleplayer campaign will take an average of 12 hours to complete. It's shorter than most games out there, but honestly, I thought the campaign had a decent length. Not too short to leave me unsatisfied, but also not too long to feel dragged out. 
There are mods for this game that can extend the playtime for those who want more out of a game over 2 decades old. Regardless of Half-Life's age, you can't go wrong with that enticing $10.00 price tag.

[b]Rating: A Half-Life worth experiencing.[/b]
To sum up, Half-Life is an innovative FPS with platforming and puzzle sections included. The story is compelling, and the gameplay is without a doubt, the best part of what this game has to offer. 
This game is a must buy for anyone with a Steam account. If you don't already have it, I strongly recommend you do get it in order to experience a classic that builds a fascinating world which is expanded upon in the sequel and Half-Life expansions: Opposing Force and Blue Shift.
I'd rate Half-Life at an 8/10. While the game has aged after 2 decades of its release, its aged like a fine wine.
My favorite game of all time, and it's still fun in 2021. A masterpiece.
Piringo recomendar this juego, estar very bueno lo mismo que el 2

Would I recommend Half-Life? Does a bear shit on the pope? The answer to both of these questions is: You bet your big ass. I was a wee boy when this and Rob Halford came out. Heck, I don't think I'd heard of it until first playing it in 2006. I loved it then and still do, having just beaten it, and this game too, in 2021 as of typing this. You play as Morgan Freeman, a silent scientist dude entering a research facility, where shit quickly hits the fan and aliens invade the place. You know how it is.

Armed at first with the iconic crowbar, you must escape, along the way fighting these aliens, and marines also jumping in to hunt you down. It reminds me of Rambo, in that you're a one-man army blasting your way through all these blokes with their machine guns and grenades and helicopters and whatnot. There's a nice selection of standard weapons for you to pick up. The explosives are my favourite. They blow things to bits. And then there's a few alien weapons.

Where it really shines is with it's immersive feel, using a seamless narrative viewed entirely by the player's point of view, and scripted events, all of which were revolutionary for the time and have inspired countless games that have also used these features. Here's looking at you, Call of Duty. Exploring teeny areas like vents and tunnels and solving puzzles is pretty satisfying too. Although the infamous Headcrabs (crawling vaginas with teeth and claws) tend to hide round corners in those dinky places and jump at you. They're bitches. And quite scary at times. Especially when they're latched onto a now-zombified scientist, coming after your ass.

Graphics and special effects have of course come on leaps and bounds in the last 23 years, but these were bum good for back then, and not too distractingly bad to look at now. At least not for me. I'm not down with the kids and their 4Ks and their 60fps thingymajiggies. There aren't many character models in it though, and you'll see the same Chris-Whitty-and-Albert-Einstein looking-ass scientists throughout.

The last section, where you exit the facility and teleport to the alien world of Xen (spoiler alert) is probably the weakest and disjointed part, with awkward death defying platforming (I died A LOT. Thank G-man for autosave) and a boss called Gonarch, who is a giant crab thing with a massive ballsack and shoots cum at you. Anyway, I haven't played the finally-finished fan remake Black Mesa yet, but if it goes on sale you can bet your Big Billy Bass (that's Louisiana slang for Ass, probably) I will get it.

10/10
A good game from the late-90s, great example of where modern shooters came from.
